course.subject: MATH
course.name: Matrix Computation
course.description: This course will introduce some basic matrix analysis theory and some popular matrix computation algorithms, and illustrate how they are actually used in data science. Specific topics include advanced linear algebra such as orthogonal projections and vector and matrix norms; the theories and computations of matrix factorizations such as QR decomposition, Singular Value Decomposition (SVD), and Schur decomposition; and applications to data analysis problems such as principle component analysis via SVD and collaborative filtering via matrix completion.
course.prerequisites: MATH 2111 OR MATH 2121 OR MATH 2131 OR MATH 2350

I want to give F, poor notes and boring teaching.

What professor do in lecture is copy his hand-written notes that already uploaded on Canvas and post it on Canvas as the "real time lecture notes". The "real time lecture notes" are dumb as he put all chapters in one file. It is disaster when reviewing his hand writing and unorganized notes (some sentences show half at the previous page and another half is at the next page). The only good thing in the "real time lecture notes" is contain fewer mistakes than the original one.

He explains things very detail but I cannot focus his voice and always want to sleep.

most people get full in the HW and Quiz, having fd study together will definitely help.

mean ~47%

reviews.comment_workload:
Normal workload:
HW every 2 weeks
Quiz every 3 weeks

Professor always upload the HW late so you only have 1 week to do it. The professor will not make an announcement when a new assignment is posted, so you need to keep checking Canvas. Beware that a new assignment may post during study break. (Someone did not notice it and got 0)

HW consists of 5 - 6 questions with 1 computation, 1 coding question, several proof questions. The computation and coding questions are easy and dumb since I just copied the algorithm in the lecture notes and score full. However, sometimes the proof questions are not easy.

Each quiz has some computation and some proof questions. Those proofs require knowledge beyond the lectures. The quizzes are closed book and not allow calculator. Various students cheat in the quizzes, but the TA only said "You can't fool me, you fool yourself." I am not sure whether they received adequate punishment.

Final consists of 7 questions with 17 sub-questions. Professor said the final will be similar to HW but the final is not similar to HW. Lier! The difficulty is similar to the quizzes. Although it is open book, I don't think it help.

reviews.comment_teaching:
I did not find Professor Cai's teaching very intuitive. It was not my cup of tea. I usually have the plain Tea or a HK-style milk tea from McDonald's. But this cup of tea was perhaps hand-made by crushing the dead tree leaves found near the campus.

My main confusions lied in algorithms. Every single topic has an algorithm with it. I had not taken any courses on algorithms.

One of the assignment questions was to evaluate time complexity or whatever, but we didn't learn anything related to that very thoroughly! (What we had to do is use the T(n) recurrence thing and solve it which I know now after taking COMP3711) I thought it was a bit ridiculous that an algorithms course was not a pre-requisite to this course because so many instances, it was just about algorithms.

I do appreciate the professor's willingness to answer questions during lecture though and he seemed like an smiley dude. He would also draw diagrams at certain points which increased my intuition.

I think teaching needs to be dumbed down further because not everybody has a solid foundation of linear algebra or algorithms. At least, I feel like he should tell us which knowledge is new and which is already learnt before. Intentional and clear transitions between topics did not exist. A foggy cloud could form in your path at any given moment.

reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is pretty light, since there's only one homework (5-6 questions) every other week. There was a quiz during the tutorial every three weeks, but it was kinda weird since you only have 30-40 minutes to do them and the questions were either super easy or very difficult.

The final had 7 questions, and the first 5 questions (~75 points) were very standard. (e.g. compute the LU decomposition of some matrix, solve the least squared equation) If you revised at all, you should have been able to do them. The last two questions were less obvious though, and I don't think many people got them correct. I finished the first 5 questions in an hour n then spent the next two hours thinking about how to solve the last two questions. There was no paper check afterwards so I still have no idea what the answer is tbh.

reviews.author: Lucien▪Evans
reviews.comment_content: The algorithms covered in this course are useful for students majoring in Applied MATH/ PHYS/ DSCT .....
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. CAI is a passionate professor with poor accent and his teaching style is boring.

If you plan to work on projects with MATLAB, this course will save your time by covering essential algorithms. Despite the fact Prof.CAI spends a considerable amount of time writing out each line of the algorithms on the whiteboard, which can be boring and unnecessary, it is still worthwhile.

Also, what he taught in lecture are mostly same with his handwriting notes.

However, i still suggest you to attend his lecture although it is boring if you want to perform well in exam. Simply reading his handwriting notes sometimes is not enough for you to finish HW and perform well in exam. He will give you some tricks on remembering the algorithms, and mainly focus on the contents that would be tested in final.

I remember there existed one algorithm involving Givens matrix in final exam, which was easy to be confused with a normal algorithm. You can't find it in lecture notes but it was taught in lecture actually.
reviews.comment_grading:
My grade: A

40%HW+60%Final.

It appears that the exam and HW in the past few years were too easy, resulting in everyone achieving high scores. In response, Prof.CAI increased the difficulty of final and HW significantly.

Both HW and Final are quite challenging. For each assignment, i will spend more than half a day to finish and still have lots of problems could't solve. Trying to find a classmate doing HW with you is really helpful.  

In each assignment, he asked you to finish lots of MATH problems such as SPD, block matrix. Most questions are proof and analysis instead of simple calculation.

I scored near the upper quartile in 4/5 assignments and achieved mean score in 1 assignment.

Got nearly high in Final although i didn't solve two 10 score algorithms in the last question. The previous problems, excluding the last question, are not difficult to solve, as long as you attend the lectures and carefully complete HW.  So it is not that tough to perform well in final even if i can't solve the last questions at all.

Final statistics:
My score: 78
Mean: 49.56 Median: 52 High: 84
Upper Quartile: 62 Lower Quartile: 37

He only gave me A. Damn it!

If MATH3322 is not your major required course, it is not recommended to be taken. You have to endure the poor teaching quality and spend a significant amount of time on assignments that go beyond the course material, in order to achieve a high grade.

reviews.comment_workload:
Undoubtedly heavy. For me, a year 2 DSCT student, I believe that it is the second most heaviest workload course. (The most heaviest one is MATH 2121 of 2023 Fall). Frankly speaking, I have no idea whether I have missed some knowledge before getting into this course because I am very confused when I first heard the concept of Big-O and pseudo-code. Therefore, I just spent tons of time on searching for the related sources.

For the homework, it will be distributed twice a week and you only have 1 week to finish them. There are 1 easy calculation question in each homework and 1-2 matlab code questions, and the rest are all difficult PROOF, PROOF and PROOF. You can not even have idea on those proofs even you pay 200% attention to the lectures. Sometimes you need to find the idea from the essays written by the professors from other oversea university.
Tell you a fact, some of the contents of this course is same as the postgraduate level of some courses of CUHK.


The following is a very important reminder:

YOU SHOULD ATTEND EACH TUTORIAL SESSION !!!!!!

The tutorial session will tell you the answers of the previous homework. NO RECORDING IS APPLIED and the only way to obtain them is to copy all the stuffs on the whiteboard and recite all of them for the final. This is very important because there are 1-2 questions in final are very similar to certain homework questions.

IT SAVES 10 MARKS OF MY FINAL EXAM, which is 6 points of your FINAL GRADE.

reviews.author: Daniel Kao
reviews.title: Easy but dumb and useless course. also the prof's English sucks
reviews.comment_content:
1. LU Decomposition
2. QR Decomposition
3. Eigenvalue Decomposition
4. SVD Decomposition

Basically, the prof went thru every decomposition methods about the hand-writing process and algorithm. All you need to do is just memorizing the steps. There are indeed some proof questions in the hw, but not many in the exam.

Besides those 4 topics, he briefly introduced the applications of each topic as well, for example, using QR to solve least square problems.

The reason I give a C in this part is because I think I didn't learn many new stuff as I expected. I mean, as a 3000-level math course, the content doesn't ask you to think in yourself but keeps memorizing things.

Also, the algorithm is not that useful as well, since there have already been a lot of easy-to-use toolkits and resources for matrix computation like numpy in python. However, there would be 1 question for matlab in each assignment, which was dumb too. (The algorithm is stated in the course material, you just need to copy and paste...) So maybe they need to think about the course content and update it from time to time. It's a little bit out of date.

reviews.author: TerryWu
reviews.title: Unexpectedly Good Grade (No Kidding)
reviews.comment_content:
Course Syllabus:
1. Introduction
2. Basic Linear Algebra (Review of MATH2121 & Norm)
3. LU Decomposition
4. Case Studies A (Page Rank & Image Decomvolution)
5. QR Decomposition
6. Case Studies B (Least Squares Problem & Simple Linear Regression)
7. Eigenvalue Decomposition (Power Iteration Methods)
8. Case Studies C (Find Polynomial Roots & Spectral Clustering/Graph Cut)
9. Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) & Best k-rank Approximation
10. Case Studies D (Least Squares Problem & Principle Component Analysis(PCA))

DSCT major requirement.
This course is basically about the major matrix operations, decompositions (algorithm + practical implements) and applications.
There is always a case study referring to each major topic as shown in the syllabus.

As this course covers algorithms, basic algorithms knowledge (e.g. big O notations) is preferred to understand this course (I took COMP3711 meanwhile and I have finished COMP2711). Professor would not explain those algorithm preliminaries in details as he might think that we have already known them. It is easier for you to finish the homework with those knowledge as some homeworks require you to give out algorithms in specific time complexity (e.g. O(n^2) ).
reviews.comment_teaching:
I personally think that Professor CAI has delivered a good teaching pace and style throughout this virtual semester. Some students may not like his relatively stronger accent, but I can really tell that he has a lot to teach us and he is working hard to do so (unfortunately he cannot cover the algorithm of SVD and its case study).

For case studies, I actually like them very much since they are all about the practical application of these not-good-looking algorithms. You would not feel that what you learned in this course are just textbook knowledge irrelevant to real life.

Conclusion: Never judge a professor by his/her accent first.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme:
40% Homework (every two weeks, 6 in total)
30% Quizzes (3 in total)
30% Final Exam

I got:
Homework: 39.33%
Quizzes: 24.9%
Final: 26.4% (88/100 pts)

In total: 90.63%
I was expecting B+ ~ A- since the overall content is not that difficult and I fucked up 2 quizzes but it turned out that I got A finally.
Tbh I am really shocked by the good grades the professor gave this semester.
Thanks a lot Prof. CAI :D
reviews.comment_workload:
Total workload is quite light.

Except last homework, there is always a problem requiring MATLAB coding. TA would give out a MATLAB manual on Canvas without explicitly teaching it. One may say the heaviest workload lies in understanding the MATLAB syntax (then you will know how light the workload is).

For final preparation, professor gave out a sample final before real final this semester. They are very similar and you can assure around 60-70 points if you completely understand the sample final.
